GOD.content: plays the spokesman of the fabled reader standing before a secret
GOD.linkedContent: plays the spokesman of the fabled reader standing before a secret

GT.content: Derrida reels us in from a temporizing detour
GT.linkedContent: Derrida reels us in from a temporizing detour

R.content: Derrida speaking from the bottom of his heart: the excessive gift goes straight to his heart, to what he holds dear, to what holds him > any words of welcome (hospitality) too modest
R.linkedContent: Derrida speaking from the bottom of his heart: the excessive gift goes straight to his heart, to what he holds dear, to what holds him > any words of welcome (hospitality) too modest

R.content: lacks a temerity Nancy possesses [re: freedom] [too conciliatory to Nancy? see also TN]
R.linkedContent: lacks a temerity Nancy possesses [re: freedom] [too conciliatory to Nancy? see also TN]

R.content: I have used “democracy to come” irresponsibly, leaving a reserve of excessive responsibility
R.linkedContent: I have used “democracy to come” irresponsibly, leaving a reserve of excessive responsibility

R.content: the rogue that therefore I am: (ab)using time

MONL.content: “can the passion of a Franco-Maghrebian martyr testify to this universal destiny which assigns us to a single language while prohibiting us from appropriating it”
MONL.linkedContent: “can the passion of a Franco-Maghrebian martyr testify to this universal destiny which assigns us to a single language while prohibiting us from appropriating it”

MONL.content: I will be accused of confusing it all, of course I am not; p. 41 each of my favorite languages
MONL.linkedContent: I will be accused of confusing it all, of course I am not; p. 41 each of my favorite languages

MONL.content: doesn’t like certain accents; [on his demand for purity of language] it simply exposes me to suffering when someone, who can be myself, happens to fall short of it
MONL.linkedContent: doesn’t like certain accents; [on his demand for purity of language] it simply exposes me to suffering when someone, who can be myself, happens to fall short of it

MONL.content: someone in Derrida flatters himself to understand a domineering murmur beyond grammar, bow to a more hidden rule, last will of language entrusted only to me [see p. 49], last heir of French language: play the role of hero-martyr-pioneer-outlaw-legislator [Nietzsche]
MONL.linkedContent: someone in Derrida flatters himself to understand a domineering murmur beyond grammar, bow to a more hidden rule, last will of language entrusted only to me [see p. 49], last heir of French language: play the role of hero-martyr-pioneer-outlaw-legislator [Nietzsche]

MONL.content: I always surrender myself to language: give credit to that which is to come (as opposed to the given)
MONL.linkedContent: I always surrender myself to language: give credit to that which is to come (as opposed to the given)

MONL.content: Derrida risks infantile presumptuousness of infantile allegations (“I am the last Jew”) to be honest: “I always tell the truth, you can believe me.”
MONL.linkedContent: Derrida risks infantile presumptuousness of infantile allegations (“I am the last Jew”) to be honest: “I always tell the truth, you can believe me.”

MONL.content: Derrida’s an incomprehensible guest in French language
Derrida experienced catastrophe as a paradoxical opportunity: bottomless alienation of the soul
MONL.linkedContent: Derrida experienced catastrophe as a paradoxical opportunity: bottomless alienation of the soul

MONL.content: always easier to bless my destiny, I write blindly, using machines, seeking to touch the one to thank for the gift of language > day I knew to whom to render thanks, I would know everything, I could die
MONL.linkedContent: always easier to bless my destiny, I write blindly, using machines, seeking to touch the one to thank for the gift of language > day I knew to whom to render thanks, I would know everything, I could die

MONL.content: Derrida has the illusion he cultivates his own desert, whereas a hostage’s place was reserved for him, as a summons (mise en demeure)
MONL.linkedContent: Derrida has the illusion he cultivates his own desert, whereas a hostage’s place was reserved for him, as a summons (mise en demeure)

OOG.content: [Derrida “affirms” phenomenology after “savaging” it] “how can we lament that phenomenology is not an ontology”
OOG.linkedContent: [Derrida “affirms” phenomenology after “savaging” it] “how can we lament that phenomenology is not an ontology”

FK.content: [Derrida’s liberalism?] unreserved taste for democratic public space, lights of Enlightenment, emancipation from religious dogmatism, thus the attempt to try to think religion w/in limits of reason alone, an epoché that “gives a chance to a political event” [see “Sauf le nom”], belongs to history of democracy
FK.linkedContent: [Derrida’s liberalism?] unreserved taste for democratic public space, lights of Enlightenment, emancipation from religious dogmatism, thus the attempt to try to think religion w/in limits of reason alone, an epoché that “gives a chance to a political event” [see “Sauf le nom”], belongs to history of democracy

FK.content: “by what right do I authorize myself to take these detours”
FK.linkedContent: “by what right do I authorize myself to take these detours”

FL.content: Derrida’s response to accusation of nihilism

LOBL.content: in one’s most mournful glory: “turn oneself into a mouthful,” swallow oneself so as to be close to oneself, absolute knowledge [this is from GLAS]
LOBL.linkedContent: in one’s most mournful glory: “turn oneself into a mouthful,” swallow oneself so as to be close to oneself, absolute knowledge [this is from GLAS]

MC.content: “my clinamen has to do w/ the divisibility of the mark”
MC.linkedContent: “my clinamen has to do w/ the divisibility of the mark”

AF.content: Derrida identifies w/ Marranos (don’t tell anyone)

in response to Derrida’s statement that L’Un se garde de l’autre pour se faire violence can only be said/ thus archived so economically in French, Bennington wonders if Derrida committed violent election of the one: Derrida says he never spoke of absolute untranslatibility, and that his affirmation of idiomaticity is always one of deferral & impurity [both were ironic?]
AF.linkedContent: in response to Derrida’s statement that L’Un se garde de l’autre pour se faire violence can only be said/ thus archived so economically in French, Bennington wonders if Derrida committed violent election of the one: Derrida says he never spoke of absolute untranslatibility, and that his affirmation of idiomaticity is always one of deferral & impurity [both were ironic?]

POO.content: X (a child, Pierre, a trace) does not need your, the father’s name, does not return your, the father’s name [Derrida’s thinly veiled reference to Pierre]
POO.linkedContent: X (a child, Pierre, a trace) does not need your, the father’s name, does not return your, the father’s name [Derrida’s thinly veiled reference to Pierre]

POO.content: Philoctetus: the child is the problem [shield], always, that is the truth
POO.linkedContent: Philoctetus: the child is the problem [shield], always, that is the truth

SPOM.content: Derrida refers to being imprisoned in Prague
SPOM.linkedContent: Derrida refers to being imprisoned in Prague

FWT.content: I’m a madman (comic/tragic) dying to be unfaithful in the spirit of fidelity
FWT.linkedContent: I’m a madman (comic/tragic) dying to be unfaithful in the spirit of fidelity

FWT.content: Derrida recognizes in himself the figure of an heir, in a deliberate, often happy way
FWT.linkedContent: Derrida recognizes in himself the figure of an heir, in a deliberate, often happy way

FWT.content: “I have always forbidden myself to injure or put to death” [avoid putting to death by reaffirming heritage] [don’t let dead bury the dead]
FWT.linkedContent: “I have always forbidden myself to injure or put to death” [avoid putting to death by reaffirming heritage] [don’t let dead bury the dead]

FWT.content: contradictory/uncomfortable double injunction: mad for an absolute past, past whose (im)measure that of bottomless memory, while dreading nostalgia, fixation, cult of remembrance: nothing seems desirable save in this injunction > leave life in life & make it live again [this “heir]
FWT.linkedContent: contradictory/uncomfortable double injunction: mad for an absolute past, past whose (im)measure that of bottomless memory, while dreading nostalgia, fixation, cult of remembrance: nothing seems desirable save in this injunction > leave life in life & make it live again [this “heir]

FWT.content: Derrida now seen as much too sophisticated or uselessly subtle
FWT.linkedContent: Derrida now seen as much too sophisticated or uselessly subtle

FWT.content: in Derrida’s [torrid relation w/] touching/mistreating (toucher à) the French language, letting himself be touched/mistreated, in his attention not to signifier but to letter, address, destination, he is closest to Lacan, but “Lacan is so French!”, “so much more French than I am”
FWT.linkedContent: in Derrida’s [torrid relation w/] touching/mistreating (toucher à) the French language, letting himself be touched/mistreated, in his attention not to signifier but to letter, address, destination, he is closest to Lacan, but “Lacan is so French!”, “so much more French than I am”

FWT.content: btwn French language & me there will have been, will be, more love, mad love, reciprocal jealousy [i.e. the insane idea that French language is jealous of Derrida]
FWT.linkedContent: btwn French language & me there will have been, will be, more love, mad love, reciprocal jealousy [i.e. the insane idea that French language is jealous of Derrida]

FWT.content: Derrida’s wares are more perverse, contraband, than his father’s (sees his father as exemplary figure of the victim, of “sacrifice,” voûté); perhaps Derrida is avenging his father by introducing disorder into “commerce,” whose trial he would be organizing
FWT.linkedContent: Derrida’s wares are more perverse, contraband, than his father’s (sees his father as exemplary figure of the victim, of “sacrifice,” voûté); perhaps Derrida is avenging his father by introducing disorder into “commerce,” whose trial he would be organizing

FWT.content: specular countersignature, re: communitarianism of oppressed, reactive self-defense, too symmetrical of a response [Derrida couldn’t tolerate being “integrated” into Jewish school]
FWT.linkedContent: specular countersignature, re: communitarianism of oppressed, reactive self-defense, too symmetrical of a response [Derrida couldn’t tolerate being “integrated” into Jewish school]

FWT.content: “matrix” of OG: conditioned all my later work
FWT.linkedContent: “matrix” of OG: conditioned all my later work

FWT.content: “independence & contradiction: there is nothing I understand better”
FWT.linkedContent: “independence & contradiction: there is nothing I understand better”

P.content: all theories of art (Plato, Heidegger, Hegel, Husserl), you have to know what you’re talking about—can’t just say, via Rousseau, “I find the palace capitalistic,” this is extrinsic [Derrida makes a pretty good joke!]
P.linkedContent: all theories of art (Plato, Heidegger, Hegel, Husserl), you have to know what you’re talking about—can’t just say, via Rousseau, “I find the palace capitalistic,” this is extrinsic [Derrida makes a pretty good joke!]

POS.content: Derrida often reproached for being insistent or monotonous, and is often misunderstood to be the proprietor [i.e. of the “history of meaning”] of what he analyzes
POS.linkedContent: Derrida often reproached for being insistent or monotonous, and is often misunderstood to be the proprietor [i.e. of the “history of meaning”] of what he analyzes

POS.content: Derrida does not read to say yes or no to a text
POS.linkedContent: Derrida does not read to say yes or no to a text

POS.content: Derrida’s texts belong neither to “philosophical” nor “literary” register, communicate w/ other texts that can be called “philosophical” or “literary” acc. a kind of paleonomy
POS.linkedContent: Derrida’s texts belong neither to “philosophical” nor “literary” register, communicate w/ other texts that can be called “philosophical” or “literary” acc. a kind of paleonomy

ROP.linkedContent: I love memory, how else can one love?

OTO.content: 4 “I settle accounts, however I can, on a certain number of problems”
OTO.linkedContent: 4 “I settle accounts, however I can, on a certain number of problems”

ATIA.content: secondariness of “I am living” to “I think,” unthought side of a thinking of life, a “living present”: thus began deconstruction, w/ Husserl & everything that followed, questioning autobiography of ego in its living present

DPi.linkedContent: [Joke] “perhaps you remember, it was last century” [lecture on January 12, 2000]

DPi.linkedContent: having used the internet to find information on DP, Derrida adds, “I am not sanctifying the web”

LI.linkedContent: countless games Derrida has played w/ Ja, Der, Da [Ja Re-Da]
